Tags: biconditional-elimination-1 python declaration class

BiconditionalElimination1Declaration (python class)

See also

math concept | python inclusion class | python sample

This section presents the BiconditionalElimination1Declaration python class.

This class models the declaration of the biconditional-elimination-1 inference-rule in the target universe-of-discourse.

Punctilious users do not need to instanciate objects from this class. In effect, the UniverseOfDiscourse class exposes the biconditional_elimination_1 property, and instanciation is automatic when the property is accessed for the first time.

class punctilious.BiconditionalElimination1Declaration(universe_of_discourse, echo=None)

The well-known biconditional elimination #1 inference rule: P ⟺ Q ⊢ P ⟹ Q.

Acronym: be1.

compose_paragraph_proof(o)

This method should be overridden by specialized inference-rule classes to provide accurate proofs.

Return type:

Generator[Composable, Composable, bool]

infer_formula(p_iff_q=None, t=None, echo=None)

This python method does not verify the validity of the arguments, applies the inference-rule algorithm, and returns a formula.

Note

Note the critical distinction between the infer_formula and the infer_formula_statement methods. The former does not verify the validity of the arguments, applies the inference-rule algorithm, and produces a formula that may be invalid . The later verifies the validity of the arguments, applies the inference-rule algorithm, and produces a formula-statement that is valid by definition.

verify_args(p_iff_q=None, t=None)

Verify the syntactical-compatibility of input statements and return True if they are compatible, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool
